storyTitle: As Scheduler, I want to detect overlapping appointments to prevent double-booking resources

testCases.title: Detect overlapping appointments for the same resource
preconditions: User is logged in with Scheduler role
Scheduling system is accessible and operational
Resource A exists in the system and is available
No existing appointments for Resource A in the test time window
User has permissions to create appointments

steps.action: Navigate to the appointment creation page
steps.expectedResult: Appointment creation form is displayed with all required fields

steps.action: Select Resource A from the resource dropdown
steps.expectedResult: Resource A is selected and displayed in the resource field

steps.action: Set appointment start time to 10:00 and end time to 11:00
steps.expectedResult: Time fields are populated with 10:00 to 11:00

steps.action: Fill in all other required appointment details and click Save
steps.expectedResult: Appointment is saved successfully and confirmation message is displayed

steps.action: Navigate back to appointment creation page to create a second appointment
steps.expectedResult: New appointment creation form is displayed

steps.action: Select Resource A from the resource dropdown
steps.expectedResult: Resource A is selected and displayed in the resource field

steps.action: Set appointment start time to 10:30 and end time to 11:30
steps.expectedResult: Time fields are populated with 10:30 to 11:30

steps.action: Fill in all other required appointment details and click Save
steps.expectedResult: System detects overlap and flags conflict immediately with a conflict warning message

steps.action: Review conflict details displayed in the UI
steps.expectedResult: Conflict information shows both appointment times (10:00-11:00 and 10:30-11:30), appointment IDs, and Resource A identifier

postconditions: First appointment remains saved in the system
Second appointment is not saved due to conflict
Conflict details are logged in the system
Scheduler is aware of the conflict and can take corrective action

testCases.title: Ensure conflict detection latency is under 2 seconds
preconditions: User is logged in with Scheduler role
Scheduling system is operational
At least one existing appointment is present in the system
Timer or performance monitoring tool is available
System is under normal load conditions

steps.action: Start timer and navigate to appointment creation or update page
steps.expectedResult: Page loads successfully and timer is running

steps.action: Create or update an appointment that overlaps with an existing appointment
steps.expectedResult: Appointment details are entered successfully

steps.action: Click Save and measure time until conflict detection completes
steps.expectedResult: System processes conflict detection and displays result within 2 seconds

steps.action: Verify conflict flag appears in UI immediately after detection
steps.expectedResult: Conflict flag is visible without noticeable delay, clearly indicating the overlap

steps.action: Simulate concurrent operations by having multiple users create appointments simultaneously
steps.expectedResult: System handles concurrent requests without errors

steps.action: Measure conflict detection latency during concurrent operations
steps.expectedResult: System maintains latency under 2 seconds SLA during concurrent operations with no performance degradation

postconditions: Conflict detection performance meets SLA requirements
System remains responsive under load
All conflict detections are logged with timestamps
No appointments are saved with undetected conflicts

testCases.title: Support conflict detection across time zones
preconditions: User is logged in with Scheduler role
System supports multiple time zones
Resource is available for scheduling
User's time zone is configured in their profile
System can handle time zone conversions

steps.action: Navigate to appointment creation page
steps.expectedResult: Appointment creation form is displayed

steps.action: Select a resource and set time zone to 'America/New_York' (Time Zone A)
steps.expectedResult: Time zone A is selected and displayed

steps.action: Create an appointment from 14:00 to 15:00 EST and save
steps.expectedResult: Appointment is saved successfully with correct time zone metadata (EST) displayed in confirmation

steps.action: Navigate to create a new appointment for the same resource
steps.expectedResult: New appointment creation form is displayed

steps.action: Select the same resource and set time zone to 'Europe/London' (Time Zone B)
steps.expectedResult: Time zone B is selected and displayed

steps.action: Create an overlapping appointment from 19:00 to 20:00 GMT (equivalent to 14:00-15:00 EST) and attempt to save
steps.expectedResult: System detects conflict considering time zone differences and displays conflict warning

steps.action: Review the conflict alert details
steps.expectedResult: Conflict alert shows appointment times adjusted to user's time zone with both original time zones indicated (14:00-15:00 EST and 19:00-20:00 GMT shown as equivalent)

steps.action: Verify that both appointments display correct local times in the conflict details
steps.expectedResult: System correctly converts and displays times, clearly showing the overlap despite different time zone representations

postconditions: First appointment remains saved with Time Zone A metadata
Second appointment is blocked due to detected conflict
Time zone conversion is accurate and logged
Conflict alert displays times in user's preferred time zone

storyTitle: As Scheduler, I want to detect double-booking of resources across multiple schedules to avoid resource conflicts

testCases.title: Detect double-booking of resource across multiple schedules
preconditions: User is logged in with Scheduler role
Multiple schedules (Schedule 1 and Schedule 2) exist in the system
Resource B exists and is shared across both schedules
User has access to both Schedule 1 and Schedule 2
No existing appointments for Resource B in the test time window
System can aggregate data from multiple calendars

steps.action: Navigate to Schedule 1 appointment creation page
steps.expectedResult: Schedule 1 appointment creation form is displayed

steps.action: Select Resource B from the resource dropdown
steps.expectedResult: Resource B is selected and displayed

steps.action: Set appointment start time to 14:00 and end time to 15:00
steps.expectedResult: Time fields show 14:00 to 15:00

steps.action: Fill in all required appointment details and click Save
steps.expectedResult: Appointment is saved successfully in Schedule 1 with confirmation message displayed

steps.action: Navigate to Schedule 2 appointment creation page
steps.expectedResult: Schedule 2 appointment creation form is displayed

steps.action: Select Resource B from the resource dropdown
steps.expectedResult: Resource B is selected and displayed

steps.action: Set appointment start time to 14:30 and end time to 15:30
steps.expectedResult: Time fields show 14:30 to 15:30

steps.action: Fill in all required appointment details and click Save
steps.expectedResult: System detects double-booking across schedules and flags conflict immediately with warning message

steps.action: Review conflict details displayed in the UI
steps.expectedResult: Conflict information shows both appointments (14:00-15:00 from Schedule 1 and 14:30-15:30 from Schedule 2), appointment IDs, Resource B identifier, and both schedule names

postconditions: Appointment in Schedule 1 remains saved
Appointment in Schedule 2 is blocked due to conflict
Conflict is logged with details of both schedules
Resource B availability status is accurate across both schedules

testCases.title: Ensure conflict detection latency under 3 seconds
preconditions: User is logged in with Scheduler role
Multiple schedules are configured in the system
At least one existing appointment exists that can cause a double-booking
Timer or performance monitoring tool is available
System is operational under normal load

steps.action: Start timer and navigate to appointment creation page in any schedule
steps.expectedResult: Appointment creation form loads and timer is running

steps.action: Create or update an appointment that causes a double-booking with an existing appointment in another schedule
steps.expectedResult: All appointment details are entered successfully

steps.action: Click Save and measure time until conflict detection completes
steps.expectedResult: System detects conflict and displays result within 3 seconds

steps.action: Stop timer and record the latency
steps.expectedResult: Recorded latency is under 3 seconds

steps.action: Verify conflict alert is visible in the UI
steps.expectedResult: Alert is displayed promptly in UI with clear conflict details and no noticeable delay

postconditions: Conflict detection latency meets the 3-second SLA
Conflict alert is visible to the user
Performance metrics are logged
Double-booked appointment is not saved

testCases.title: Prevent saving double-booked appointments without override
preconditions: Two user accounts exist: one with override permission and one without
User without override permission is logged in
Multiple schedules exist in the system
An existing appointment creates potential for double-booking
System has role-based access control configured

steps.action: As user without override permission, navigate to appointment creation page
steps.expectedResult: Appointment creation form is displayed

steps.action: Create an appointment that double-books a resource already scheduled in another schedule
steps.expectedResult: Appointment details are entered

steps.action: Attempt to save the double-booked appointment
steps.expectedResult: System blocks save operation and displays error message indicating double-booking conflict and insufficient permissions to override

steps.action: Verify that the appointment was not saved to the system
steps.expectedResult: Appointment does not appear in any schedule and database shows no new record

steps.action: Log out and log in as user with override permission
steps.expectedResult: User with override permission is successfully logged in

steps.action: Navigate to appointment creation page and create the same double-booked appointment
steps.expectedResult: Appointment details are entered and conflict is detected

steps.action: Acknowledge the conflict warning and select the override option
steps.expectedResult: Override option is available and can be selected

steps.action: Attempt to save with override permission enabled
steps.expectedResult: System allows save operation, displays confirmation message, and shows override warning acknowledgment

steps.action: Verify the override action is logged in the system
steps.expectedResult: System logs override action with user ID, timestamp, appointment details, and reason for override

postconditions: Users without override permission cannot save double-booked appointments
Users with override permission can save double-booked appointments
All override actions are logged with complete audit trail
System maintains data integrity and access control

storyTitle: As Scheduler, I want the system to handle concurrent scheduling updates without conflicts to maintain data integrity

testCases.title: Handle concurrent scheduling updates without data corruption
preconditions: Scheduling system is operational and accessible
At least 2 scheduler user accounts are active and authenticated
Test appointment exists in the system with ID and version number
Database concurrency controls are enabled
Network connectivity is stable for all test users

steps.action: User 1 opens the existing appointment for editing and loads appointment details
steps.expectedResult: Appointment details are displayed with current version number and all fields are editable

steps.action: User 2 simultaneously opens the same appointment for editing
steps.expectedResult: Appointment details are displayed to User 2 with the same version number as User 1

steps.action: User 1 modifies the appointment time from 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM and clicks Save
steps.expectedResult: System successfully saves User 1's changes, increments version number, and displays success confirmation

steps.action: User 2 modifies the appointment location and clicks Save without refreshing
steps.expectedResult: System detects version mismatch and prevents save operation, displaying conflict error message

steps.action: Verify conflict notification is displayed to User 2
steps.expectedResult: Conflict notification appears within 2 seconds stating 'This appointment has been modified by another user. Please refresh and try again.'

steps.action: User 2 clicks Refresh button to reload the appointment
steps.expectedResult: Updated appointment data with User 1's changes is displayed with new version number

steps.action: User 2 reapplies their location change and clicks Save
steps.expectedResult: System successfully saves User 2's changes with correct version number and displays success confirmation

steps.action: Verify final appointment data in database
steps.expectedResult: Appointment contains both User 1's time change (3:00 PM) and User 2's location change with no data corruption or loss

postconditions: Appointment data is consistent and contains all valid changes
No data corruption occurred during concurrent updates
Version number is correctly incremented
All users can view the final updated appointment
System audit log records both update attempts and conflict resolution

testCases.title: Maintain performance under high concurrency
preconditions: Scheduling system is operational with full resources allocated
100 scheduler user accounts are created and authenticated
Test dataset contains at least 500 appointments
Performance monitoring tools are configured and running
Load testing environment is set up with concurrent user simulation capability
Baseline performance metrics are documented (response time SLA is defined)

steps.action: Configure load testing tool to simulate 100 concurrent scheduler users
steps.expectedResult: Load testing tool is configured with 100 virtual users ready to execute scheduling operations

steps.action: Start performance monitoring and capture baseline metrics (CPU, memory, database connections)
steps.expectedResult: Performance monitoring dashboard shows current system metrics and is recording data

steps.action: Initiate concurrent load test with all 100 users performing read operations (viewing appointments)
steps.expectedResult: All 100 users successfully retrieve appointment data with response times within SLA (< 2 seconds)

steps.action: Execute concurrent write operations with 100 users creating new appointments simultaneously
steps.expectedResult: System processes all create requests with response times within SLA, no timeouts or errors occur

steps.action: Execute concurrent update operations with 100 users modifying different appointments simultaneously
steps.expectedResult: All update operations complete successfully within SLA, no deadlocks or transaction failures occur

steps.action: Execute mixed operations with 50 users reading, 30 users updating, and 20 users creating appointments simultaneously
steps.expectedResult: System handles mixed workload with all operations completing within SLA thresholds

steps.action: Monitor system resource utilization during peak concurrent load
steps.expectedResult: CPU utilization remains below 80%, memory usage is stable, database connection pool has available connections

steps.action: Review performance metrics and calculate average response times across all operations
steps.expectedResult: Average response time is within SLA, 95th percentile response time does not exceed 3 seconds, zero failed transactions

steps.action: Verify data integrity by checking random sample of 50 appointments created/updated during test
steps.expectedResult: All sampled appointments contain correct data with no corruption, duplicates, or missing information

postconditions: System maintains stable performance under 100 concurrent users
No performance degradation observed during sustained load
All transactions completed successfully without data loss
System resources return to normal levels after load test completion
Performance test results are documented and meet SLA requirements

storyTitle: As Scheduler, I want the system to support multiple calendar formats for conflict detection to ensure compatibility

testCases.title: Parse and detect conflicts from iCal format
preconditions: Scheduling system is operational and accessible
Scheduler user account is authenticated
Valid iCal (.ics) test file is prepared with multiple calendar events
System has iCal parser module enabled
At least one existing appointment in the system to create potential conflicts

steps.action: Navigate to calendar import section and select 'Import Calendar' option
steps.expectedResult: Import dialog opens with file upload interface and format selection options

steps.action: Select iCal format option and browse to upload the prepared .ics test file
steps.expectedResult: File is selected and filename is displayed in the upload field

steps.action: Click 'Import' button to upload and process the iCal file
steps.expectedResult: System displays processing indicator and begins parsing the iCal data

steps.action: Verify parsing completion and review import summary
steps.expectedResult: System displays success message showing number of events parsed (e.g., '15 events successfully imported'), data is normalized and stored in system format

steps.action: Navigate to calendar view and verify imported iCal events are displayed
steps.expectedResult: All imported events from iCal file are visible with correct dates, times, titles, and descriptions

steps.action: Create a new appointment that conflicts with an imported iCal event (same date/time)
steps.expectedResult: System allows appointment creation form to be filled with conflicting time slot

steps.action: Attempt to save the conflicting appointment
steps.expectedResult: System detects the conflict with the iCal imported event and displays conflict warning message: 'Conflict detected with existing event: [Event Name] at [Time]'

steps.action: Review conflict details showing both the new appointment and the conflicting iCal event
steps.expectedResult: Conflict details panel displays both appointments side-by-side with overlapping time highlighted, iCal source is indicated

steps.action: Verify format-specific metadata is preserved by viewing iCal event properties
steps.expectedResult: iCal-specific fields (UID, SEQUENCE, DTSTAMP) are preserved and displayed in event metadata

postconditions: iCal calendar data is successfully imported and stored
All iCal events are normalized and accessible in the system
Conflict detection accurately identifies overlaps with iCal events
Format-specific metadata is preserved for audit purposes
No data loss or corruption occurred during import

testCases.title: Parse and detect conflicts from Google Calendar format
preconditions: Scheduling system is operational and accessible
Scheduler user account is authenticated
Google Calendar API integration is configured and enabled
Test Google Calendar account exists with OAuth credentials configured
Test Google Calendar contains at least 5 events
System has valid OAuth tokens for Google Calendar access

steps.action: Navigate to calendar sync section and select 'Connect Google Calendar' option
steps.expectedResult: System displays Google Calendar integration interface with 'Authorize' button

steps.action: Click 'Authorize' button to initiate OAuth authentication flow
steps.expectedResult: Google OAuth consent screen opens in new window requesting calendar access permissions

steps.action: Grant calendar read permissions and complete OAuth authorization
steps.expectedResult: Authorization completes successfully, system receives OAuth token, and user is redirected back to scheduling system

steps.action: Click 'Sync Now' button to retrieve Google Calendar events via API
steps.expectedResult: System initiates API call to Google Calendar, displays sync progress indicator

steps.action: Monitor sync process and wait for completion
steps.expectedResult: Sync completes successfully with message 'Google Calendar synced: X events imported', data is parsed and normalized

steps.action: Navigate to calendar view and verify Google Calendar events are displayed
steps.expectedResult: All synced Google Calendar events appear with correct dates, times, attendees, and descriptions, Google Calendar icon indicates source

steps.action: Verify Google Calendar-specific metadata is preserved by viewing event details
steps.expectedResult: Google Calendar event ID, organizer email, and attendee list are preserved and displayed in event properties

steps.action: Create a new appointment with date/time that conflicts with a synced Google Calendar event
steps.expectedResult: Appointment creation form accepts the conflicting time slot details

steps.action: Attempt to save the conflicting appointment
steps.expectedResult: System detects conflict with Google Calendar event and displays warning: 'Conflict detected with Google Calendar event: [Event Name] at [Time]'

steps.action: Review conflict resolution options and verify accuracy of conflict detection
steps.expectedResult: Conflict panel shows both appointments with overlapping time range highlighted, Google Calendar source is clearly indicated, conflict detection is accurate to the minute

steps.action: Verify no data loss by comparing event count before and after sync
steps.expectedResult: All Google Calendar events are accounted for, no events missing or duplicated, event data matches source calendar

postconditions: Google Calendar is successfully connected via OAuth
All Google Calendar events are synced and normalized in the system
Conflict detection accurately identifies overlaps with Google Calendar events
Google Calendar-specific metadata is preserved
No data loss or corruption occurred during sync
OAuth token is securely stored for future syncs

storyTitle: As Scheduler, I want the system to support multi-time zone scheduling to accurately detect conflicts globally

testCases.title: Verify appointment creation with time zone data
preconditions: User is logged in as a Scheduler with appointment creation permissions
Scheduling system is accessible and operational
At least two different time zones are available in the system (e.g., EST and PST)
User profile has a default local time zone configured
Database is configured to store time zone metadata

steps.action: Navigate to the appointment creation page
steps.expectedResult: Appointment creation form is displayed with all required fields including time zone selector

steps.action: Enter appointment title as 'Global Team Meeting'
steps.expectedResult: Title field accepts and displays the entered text

steps.action: Select date as current date + 7 days
steps.expectedResult: Date picker displays the selected date correctly

steps.action: Set appointment start time to 10:00 AM
steps.expectedResult: Time field displays 10:00 AM

steps.action: Set appointment end time to 11:00 AM
steps.expectedResult: Time field displays 11:00 AM

steps.action: Select time zone A (e.g., America/New_York - EST) from the time zone dropdown
steps.expectedResult: Time zone dropdown displays 'America/New_York (EST)' as selected

steps.action: Click 'Save' or 'Create Appointment' button
steps.expectedResult: System processes the request and displays success confirmation message. Appointment is saved with correct time zone metadata including zone identifier, offset, and DST information

steps.action: Navigate to appointment details page to verify stored data
steps.expectedResult: Appointment details show: Title='Global Team Meeting', Date=selected date, Time=10:00 AM - 11:00 AM, Time Zone=America/New_York (EST)

steps.action: Change user profile time zone to time zone B (e.g., America/Los_Angeles - PST)
steps.expectedResult: User profile successfully updated to PST time zone

steps.action: View the same appointment in the calendar or appointment list
steps.expectedResult: Appointment time is automatically converted and displayed correctly in local time (PST): 7:00 AM - 8:00 AM with indication that original time zone is EST

steps.action: Verify time zone conversion calculation manually (EST to PST = -3 hours)
steps.expectedResult: Displayed time matches expected conversion: 10:00 AM EST = 7:00 AM PST

postconditions: Appointment is successfully stored in database with complete time zone metadata
Appointment is visible in calendar views with correct time conversions
Time zone data integrity is maintained for future conflict detection
User can view appointment in any time zone with accurate conversions
System logs record the appointment creation with time zone information

testCases.title: Detect conflicts across different time zones
preconditions: User is logged in as a Scheduler with appointment creation permissions
Scheduling system is operational with conflict detection enabled
Multiple time zones are configured in the system (e.g., EST, PST, GMT)
Database supports time zone storage and conversion
No existing appointments in the test time window
Conflict detection algorithm is active and functioning

steps.action: Navigate to appointment creation page
steps.expectedResult: Appointment creation form is displayed with all fields including time zone selector

steps.action: Create first appointment: Title='Meeting A', Date=current date + 5 days, Time=2:00 PM - 3:00 PM, Time Zone=America/New_York (EST)
steps.expectedResult: First appointment is successfully created and saved with EST time zone

steps.action: Verify first appointment is displayed in calendar
steps.expectedResult: Meeting A appears in calendar at 2:00 PM - 3:00 PM EST

steps.action: Navigate to create a second appointment
steps.expectedResult: New appointment creation form is displayed

steps.action: Create second appointment with overlapping time in different time zone: Title='Meeting B', Date=same date as Meeting A, Time=11:00 AM - 12:00 PM, Time Zone=America/Los_Angeles (PST)
steps.expectedResult: System begins processing the appointment creation request

steps.action: Click 'Save' or 'Create Appointment' button
steps.expectedResult: System performs time zone conversion (11:00 AM PST = 2:00 PM EST) and detects conflict with Meeting A

steps.action: Observe system response to conflict detection
steps.expectedResult: System displays conflict warning message indicating: 'Conflict detected: This appointment overlaps with Meeting A (2:00 PM - 3:00 PM EST / 11:00 AM - 12:00 PM PST)'

steps.action: Review conflict details provided by the system
steps.expectedResult: Conflict message shows both appointments with their respective time zones and the converted overlapping time period

steps.action: Attempt to create third appointment with partial overlap: Title='Meeting C', Date=same date, Time=11:30 AM - 12:30 PM, Time Zone=America/Los_Angeles (PST)
steps.expectedResult: System detects partial conflict (11:30 AM - 12:00 PM PST overlaps with 2:30 PM - 3:00 PM EST portion of Meeting A) and displays appropriate conflict warning

steps.action: Create fourth appointment with no overlap: Title='Meeting D', Date=same date, Time=12:00 PM - 1:00 PM, Time Zone=America/Los_Angeles (PST)
steps.expectedResult: System converts time (12:00 PM PST = 3:00 PM EST), detects no conflict, and successfully creates the appointment

steps.action: Verify all appointments in calendar view with user time zone set to GMT
steps.expectedResult: All appointments are displayed with correct time conversions to GMT: Meeting A at 7:00 PM - 8:00 PM GMT, Meeting D at 8:00 PM - 9:00 PM GMT

postconditions: System accurately detected conflicts across different time zones
Conflicting appointments were prevented or flagged appropriately
Non-conflicting appointments were created successfully
All appointments maintain correct time zone metadata
Conflict detection logs are recorded for audit purposes
Calendar displays all appointments with accurate time zone conversions
